column4: anyone please: looking for ati radeon hd 3650 driver for ubuntu 11.04 ... please somebody...
is it not in jockey-gtk?
i'm literate but just learning linux for first time. Jockey-gtk?
is what you're speaking of a patricular pkg within ubuntu?
ie proprietary drivers. open a terminal and type jockey-gtk
that would make it harder for you. i would boot to terminal and then use jockey-text
please educate me on this process to do so cause when i have the card in and boot, i don't get a boot screen...just a black screen.
if you are going from an older ati to a newer ati its possible that there is an old config laying around. you might uninstall fglrx and go back to radeonhd and then switch to the newer card
trying to comprehend...again, i'm new to linux/ ubuntu 11.04
how do i go about of uninstalling fglrx?
we need a bit more info about the specifics. (a) what card do you currently have in there (b) did you install proprietary drivers for that card (c) what do you see on boot with the new card
i'm sure that was a very dumb question...but again, learning here.
give me a sec and i'll provide the details.

present card is a PNY GeForce 8200 and the driver's shown/ options are, NVIDIA accelerated graphics driver (version 173" (This driver is not activated.) and NVIDIA accelerated graphics driver (version current) [Recommended} This driver is activated but not currently in use.  And, I'm wanting to install ATI Radeon HD3650
ok. then i would recommend that you disable the nvidia drivers, and rename/move your /etc/X11/Xorg.conf and reboot so that you are booting with xorgs drivers
okay. my options are to "remove". would that be correct?
ok
and yes removing the nvidia drivers would disable them
okay. then for the part about rename/move your /etc/x11/Xorg.conf ??
i'm sorry for the paint by the numbers for me.
nvidia uses Xorg.conf what would not be compatible with ati. you should see it if you ls /etc/X11, and then mv /etc/X11/Xorg.conf /root
rather sudo mv ...
again, my apologies...is this information listed easily somewhere within the sytem folder or is there like a cmd in terminal to find this out, etc.?

find what out? i'm saying in your terminal type ls /etc/X11 there should be something called conf, and you can "sudo mv /etc/X11/Xorg.conf /etc/X11/Xorg.conf.nvidia" to back it up and disable it at the same time
